body:
We have a child process running a webpack dev server that occasionally throws the same error (at last we think that's where it's coming from).

```
[20767:0924/120635:INFO:CONSOLE(25774)] "[HMR] bundle rebuilding", source: http://localhost:8080/test.js (25774)
Electron Helper(20768,0x7fff7c227310) malloc: *** error for object 0x7fbc217312f0: pointer being freed was not allocated
*** set a breakpoint in malloc_error_break to debug
```
Can you try v0.33.3? We had a bug around Buffer fixed since v0.33.2.

@zcbenz It is a bit better with v0.33.3, but it still crashes after a couple of 1GB downloads. Also, the memory usage gets huge (> 3GB) when downloading the files in the child process. Here is the [crash dump with v0.33.3](https://gist.github.com/pulkit110/859bdaa98a3428300fb6)
@zcbenz Ditto. It's been much less common, but I've still gotten the same crash a couple times.

Full stack trace:

```
Thread 0 Crashed:: Dispatch queue: com.apple.main-thread
0   libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110bb1974 void std::__1::__tree<std::__1::__value_type<void*, unsigned long>, std::__1::__map_value_compare<void*, std::__1::__value_type<void*, unsigned long>, std::__1::less<void*>, true>, std::__1::allocator<std::__1::__value_type<void*, unsigned long> > >::__assign_multi<std::__1::__tree_const_iterator<std::__1::__value_type<void*, unsigned long>, std::__1::__tree_node<std::__1::__value_type<void*, unsigned long>, void*>*, long> >(std::__1::__tree_const_iterator<std::__1::__value_type<void*, unsigned long>, std::__1::__tree_node<std::__1::__value_type<void*, unsigned long>, void*>*, long>, std::__1::__tree_const_iterator<std::__1::__value_type<void*, unsigned long>, std::__1::__tree_node<std::__1::__value_type<void*, unsigned long>, void*>*, long>) + 724
1   libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110b8a93e v8::internal::Heap::FreeDeadArrayBuffersHelper(v8::internal::Isolate*, std::__1::map<void*, unsigned long, std::__1::less<void*>, std::__1::allocator<std::__1::pair<void* const, unsigned long> > >&, std::__1::map<void*, unsigned long, std::__1::less<void*>, std::__1::allocator<std::__1::pair<void* const, unsigned long> > >&) + 366
2   libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110b8a33c v8::internal::Heap::FreeDeadArrayBuffers(bool) + 908
3   libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110bbee1b v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::SweepSpaces() + 379
4   libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110bbddb5 v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::CollectGarbage() + 69
5   libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110b87f39 v8::internal::Heap::MarkCompact() + 233
6   libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110b86dea v8::internal::Heap::PerformGarbageCollection(v8::internal::GarbageCollector, v8::GCCallbackFlags) + 794
7   libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110b867ef v8::internal::Heap::CollectGarbage(v8::internal::GarbageCollector, char const*, char const*, v8::GCCallbackFlags) + 687
8   libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110b85eca v8::internal::Heap::CollectAllGarbage(int, char const*, v8::GCCallbackFlags) + 154
9   libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110b8ac60 v8::internal::Heap::RegisterNewArrayBuffer(bool, void*, unsigned long) + 576
10  libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110dbd4b7 v8::internal::Runtime::SetupArrayBuffer(v8::internal::Isolate*, v8::internal::Handle<v8::internal::JSArrayBuffer>, bool, void*, unsigned long, v8::internal::SharedFlag) + 295
11  libv8.dylib                     0x0000000110dbd8e7 v8::internal::Runtime_ArrayBufferInitialize(int, v8::internal::Object**, v8::internal::Isolate*) + 535
```

Node.js included [a backport patch from V8](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/2732) which removed the crashing path, so that's probably why Node.js doesn't crash while Electron does. And from [one of the commits](https://chromium.googlesource.com/v8/v8.git/+/1a8c38c50513f9af07ada479629a653e1cf36ff3) it fixed a crash when doing garbage collection.

Same crash (Electron 0.33.4)

@zcbenz ping, any chance this could be looked at? we are thinking of moving to latest Electron with vscode but usually want to have some weeks of testing before publishing it to the users and we are now at the beginning of a new development sprint.
@bpasero Currently we are in the middle of upgrading our OS X build machines, I'll backport the patch once the upgrade is done, which should be a few days later.
@zcbenz Thanks!
v0.33.9/0.34.0 have included the patch of V8, please report back if you still see the crash.

@zcbenz great news, will give it a try. Out of curiosity, whats the commit for the fix? I was scanning libchromiumcontent for it the other day and could not find it, otherwise I might have tried out earlier :)
It is https://github.com/atom/libchromiumcontent/commit/78e54bc39a04b758ed5167cd980cc4d9951bd629, Electron uses the `atom` branch of `libchromiumcontent`.
Ah nice, thanks for the info, that explains why I could not find it.

@zcbenz unfortunately we still see a crash on our forked process with SIGABRT. Now I wonder if this bug is really the same as the one I filed originally: https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/2999

Should we reopen this one or the other?
@bpasero Can you paste the crash report? It is probably a new crash.
I wonder if there is a platform specific issue here. While we see it easily on Mac, it seems less easy to reproduce on Windows/Linux.

@zcbenz I wish I had more info, our process is literally dying with the signal SIGABRT. I can try to instrument it to maybe catch the exception that is happening, but from what I read this signal is pretty bad.
You should be able to find the crash report from `Console.app` if you are on OS X, even the crash happened in child process.

@zcbenz with the latest changes to surpress output from the electron app, is it sufficient to run with "--enable-logging" to get this output or is there a flag to enable even more verbose logging now?
The crash report will be generated no matter whether logging is enabled.

Hmm I tried the original crashing app in this issue, it is still crashing:

```
Thread 0 Crashed:: Dispatch queue: com.apple.main-thread
0   libsystem_kernel.dylib          0x00007fff99f62286 __pthread_kill + 10
1   libsystem_c.dylib               0x00007fff8d8149b3 abort + 129
2   libsystem_malloc.dylib          0x00007fff947841cb free + 428
3   libv8.dylib                     0x000000010b1584a6 v8::internal::Heap::FreeDeadArrayBuffers(bool) + 470
4   libv8.dylib                     0x000000010b18cfdb v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::SweepSpaces() + 379
5   libv8.dylib                     0x000000010b18bf75 v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::CollectGarbage() + 69
6   libv8.dylib                     0x000000010b156259 v8::internal::Heap::MarkCompact() + 233
7   libv8.dylib                     0x000000010b15510a v8::internal::Heap::PerformGarbageCollection(v8::internal::GarbageCollector, v8::GCCallbackFlags) + 794
8   libv8.dylib                     0x000000010b154b0f v8::internal::Heap::CollectGarbage(v8::internal::GarbageCollector, char const*, char const*, v8::GCCallbackFlags) + 687
9   libv8.dylib                     0x000000010b1541ea v8::internal::Heap::CollectAllGarbage(int, char const*, v8::GCCallbackFlags) + 154
10  libv8.dylib                     0x000000010b158961 v8::internal::Heap::RegisterNewArrayBuffer(bool, void*, unsigned long) + 577
11  libv8.dylib                     0x000000010b38b677 v8::internal::Runtime::SetupArrayBuffer(v8::internal::Isolate*, v8::internal::Handle<v8::internal::JSArrayBuffer>, bool, void*, unsigned long, v8::internal::SharedFlag) + 295
12  libv8.dylib                     0x000000010b38b843 v8::internal::Runtime::SetupArrayBufferAllocatingData(v8::internal::Isolate*, v8::internal::Handle<v8::internal::JSArrayBuffer>, unsigned long, bool, v8::internal::SharedFlag) + 99
13  libv8.dylib                     0x000000010af92d2e v8::ArrayBuffer::New(v8::Isolate*, unsigned long) + 94
14  libnode.dylib                   0x000000010a5c7fcd node::Buffer::(anonymous namespace)::DefaultArrayBufferNew(v8::Isolate*, unsigned long) + 29 (node_buffer.cc:80)
```

Seems that we need to backport more patches from V8.

@zcbenz ok I found it, got a couple of crash reports, here is one: https://gist.github.com/bpasero/5c2702c458aaacb92043

They are all listed in the Console > User Diagnostic Reports > Electron Helper.

Glad you can also reproduce it.

Out of curiosity I am a bit confused about the atom branch for libchromiumcontent. When I navigate from Electron 0.33.9 or 0.34.0 through the vendor commits I end up with https://github.com/atom/libchromiumcontent/tree/5e9fb565eaec8f3f393551c5513c0b6f150ac256 where I dont see the commit for the buffer backport. But maybe the atom branch is picked up differently?

After tracking the history of V8, I found that the patch applied in V8 is not exactly them same with the one in Node, it seems that V8 team first applied the original patch but then replaced it with a more "complete" one. So we should backport this patch instead:
https://chromium.googlesource.com/v8/v8.git/+/15a0ace533f5810bf87382decbbaf4799f6cac8e%5E%21/

@bpasero Your crash report says it is because out of memory:

```
v8::internal::V8::FatalProcessOutOfMemory(char const*, bool) + 594
```

It is probably also caused by this issue, but under most cases it is because V8 can not allocate new memory.

> Out of curiosity I am a bit confused about the atom branch for libchromiumcontent. When I navigate from Electron 0.33.9 or 0.34.0 through the vendor commits I end up with https://github.com/atom/libchromiumcontent/tree/5e9fb565eaec8f3f393551c5513c0b6f150ac256 where I dont see the commit for the buffer backport. But maybe the atom branch is picked up differently?

The commit of libchromiumcontent used by Electron can be found under `script/lib/config.py`,  we took current approach because there was another internal project that also uses `libchromiumcontent`, but does not need the patches used by Electron.

Once that project becomes dead (which should be very soon), I'll merge the `atom` branch to `master`.

After applying the new patch I found the problem is still there, I also navigated V8's changelog and there doesn't seem to be more fixes on garbage collecting ArrayBuffer. And interestingly the crash only happens for process created by `cp.fork`, while the same script works good in the main process.

So it is very likely that something wrong happened when we setup the Node process, but I can't see what's going wrong there.
@zcbenz does it make any difference if you use cp.fork() from electron or actually run "electron" with the environment flag ATOM_SHELL_INTERNAL_RUN_AS_NODE?

@bpasero It is the same thing, more precisely, this works:

```
$ electron download.js
```

but this doesn't:

```
$ env ATOM_SHELL_INTERNAL_RUN_AS_NODE=1 electron download.js
```
:rocket:
@zcbenz any chance for a release so I can verify the fix?
@bpasero I will publish a release today or tomorrow, I need to do some testing for the just merged auto-updater PR.
@zcbenz all right, thanks.
@zcbenz we did some testing and it seems that this issue is resolved, very cool!

I'm experiencing what seems to be the same bug, but it does not happen after downloading but rather after creating and uploading a >1MB Buffer via a WebSocket. It does not occur when running with `nodeIntegration: false` while using the Buffer implementation from Browserify.
Running v0.36.0.
